text.p: Portuguese cash bonds opened steady and dealers expected them to spend the day consolidating at current levels while the futures market followed the higher Spanish trend.

"Now that fears of an imminent rise in U.S. interest rates have faded European bonds are taking advantage," said one dealer, but he said there were insufficient investors in the market for domestic cash bonds to benefit much.
Traders said roll-overs had boosted liquidity slightly in the futures market.
"Today we'll see futures heading higher and cash bonds consolidating without much volatility. Spreads (with 10-year Bonos) will be around -10 basis points," said another dealer.

Overnight/tomorrow next rates eased to 7.17/7.27 percent from 7.22/7.24 percent on the first day of a new accounting period for commercial bank cash reserves. The Bank of Portugal left rates unchanged.
The escudo was steady and was expected to remain in a range between 102.45 and 102.50 per mark today after closing at 102.40/43.
